app.note: SR does not emend to a nominative, but adds a note, anchored between the words mahārājādhirāja and parameśvara, which says rājaparameśvara. He may have intended an emendation to mahārājādhirāja-rājaparameśvara, but this is unwarranted.
The beginning of this passage fits the requirements of āryā or a related moraic metre, but unless SR's edition is seriously wrong, the passage as a whole is prose.

SR suggests the emdendation payaḥ-payonidhi, but unless ni is present in the original and omitted from his edition, its addition is unwarranted. I suspect that rpa is actually meant to represent ḫpa (with r used in the Devanagari to replace ṟ, which in turn may have been used in SR's manuscript to replace ḫ).
I suspect that rpi stands for ḫpi (cf. the note to line 39). If, in addition, ā is a typo for a, then the reading needs no emendation.

I follow the segmentation of the ARIE report, where this name is said to be Nannaka. Theoretically, the text could also be segmented into anukurvann annaka-. SR's commentary ignores this name and says the son of Poleyana was called Anupamaguṇa.
The ARIE report gives this name as Aytakaṁbāyā, though this may be a typo.

SR emends this word to -śirodarpaṇa-, the only difference being that in his edition the word is written with a Devanagari ra and virāma, while in his footnote (also in Devanagari) it is with the ligature rpa. An upadhmānīya may be involved (cf. the note to line 39), but I cannot offer a better reading.

I cannot confidently suggest an improvement here and give the reading exactly as printed in SR's edition. I suspect that scribal errors are coupled here with misreadings by SR, and possibly also in the preceding words nara-śiro-darpaṇa- and in praśasti- in the next line. The second word of this string may perhaps be mālyaḫ.
I find the emendation unwarranted; the name is probably a variant of candeṇa (found in the Ārumbāka grant of Bādapa).

If I understand SR's emendation correctly, then it is more in the nature of a commentary. I do not think any scribal omission happened here. The word nirbhr̥tya is probably used in the sense of nibhr̥ta naibhr̥tya. The same spelling, probably in the same sense, is found in line 20 of the Śrīpūṇḍi grant of Tāḻa II.
Since SR does not emend, I assume this is a typo.
I suppose the anusvāra is above ja, but that is not really a mistake.

div.head: Plates
div.p: That shelter of all the world sarva-lokāśraya, the supremely pious Supreme Lord parameśvara of Emperors mahārājādhirāja and Supreme Sovereign parama-bhaṭṭāraka, His Majesty Viṣṇuvardhana Bhīma II convokes the householders kuṭumbin—including foremost the territorial overseers rāṣṭrakūṭa—who reside in Śakaṭamanthanī district viṣaya and commands them as follows:

In the majestic Haihaya lineage, which is comparable to the Milk Ocean, was born one called Poleyana-rāja, endowed with honour, purity and respectability, with abundant valour in his own arm. His son of incomparable virtue, taking after his father, was Nannaka-rāja. The dear son of that king nr̥pati and of Āytakāmbā, the dear daughter of Atiratha Dhavala, is Candyana-rāja. To him, a resident of Hastinapura arising from the Haihaya lineage which is the supreme sovereign of the Gaṅgā region, the Pāriyātra mountains and the city of Māhiṣmatī, who is resplendent with ,The reading printed by SR is unintelligible here; see the apparatus to line 45. The words “man-headed mirror” (or “offering of human heads” with non-standard sandhi), “banner”, “garland”, “nourishment” and “eulogy” may be present here, I suspect a misreading, probably combined with scribal error. Given the ending virājamānāya, “who is resplendent with”, this is probably a list of insignia. we Bhīma III,See the commentary for my doubts concerning the identity of the issuer. having defeated the totality of petty kings such as Mārtaṇḍa, Pitāmaha, Vikramāditya and Yuddhamalla, on the occasion of his, Candyana’s staunchness there in that campaign, have given the village named Varaṇaveṇḍī, converted into a rent-free holding mānya by a remission of all taxes, the donation being sanctified by a libation of water. Let this be known to you.
Its boundaries are as follows. To the east, Penuṁbaṟṟu. To the south, Penuṁballi. To the west, Velmadūru. To the north, Dāmarapalli.

The boundaries of the field are as follows.I can only translate the Telugu boundary description partially and tentatively. To the east, a great dried-up tamarind tree. To the southeast, premulapadugakaditi nalla jinta. To the south, goraga pannasa. To the southwest, a nūjjuṁ tamarind tree at the triple boundary juncture. To the west, Rolivāyu. To the northwest, a great tamarind tree at the triple boundary juncture. To the north, the boundary is none other than the boundary of Vāramapalli. To the northeast, niduva paduga. Let no-one pose an obstacle to his enjoyment of his rights over it. He who does so shall go to hell, conjoined with the five great sins. So too has the reverend Vyāsa said:
He who would seize land, whether given by himself or by another, shall be born as a worm in faeces for sixty thousand years.
Who, on the other hand, protects it, shall partake of the fruit of heaven. So too it is said:
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
Over and over again, Rāmabhadra begs all these future kings: “Each in your own time, you shall respect this framework of legality that is universally applicable to kings!”

Hereby I offer my respectful obeisance añjali to all future kings on earth, whether born in my lineage or a different royal lineage, who with minds averted from sin observe this ruling dharma of mine in its integrity.
The findspot is said to be Korukoṇḍa in the ARIE report, while according to SR’s edition, it was the village Muramanda (also spelt Muramunda).

Subba Rao claims that the grant was issued by Bhīma III, but publishes neither facsimiles nor even an edition of the text that would substantiate this, starting his edition on 3 verso, where all we learn is that the issuer is a Viṣṇuvardhana. For the preceding text, all the information he releases is that The Chalukya Genealogy given in this Copper plate Grant up to the accession of the Donor King Bhima, known as Bhima, the third, tallies from second plate, first side to third plate, first side with that of this same King, Published by me. The publication he refers to is the Single Bhimavaram plate of a late Eastern Cālukya king (), which he believes mentions Bhīma III at the end of its extant text. As far as I can tell at present, the mention of Bhīma III there is possible but uncertain, while the attribution of that plate to Bhīma III is unlikely and a result of wishful thinking on Subba Rao’s part. I am likewise sceptical of attributing the present grant to Bhīma III, pending a study of the actual plate or a surrogate.

Reported in 35A/1961-622 with description at 62. Partially editedThe edition only gives the text from the beginning of 3v onward, even though the preceding text would be essential in establishing Subba Rao's claim that these plates were issued by Bhīma III. See also the commentary. from the original (before the ARIE report) by R. Subba Rao (), with a summary of the contents, without facsimiles. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on Subba Rao's edition, with silent correction of inconsequential, presumably typographic mistakes. Lacking a facsimile, all my corrections are conjectural.
